column1:
5.6.4	
Pharmacological management
5.6.4.1	
Drugs for urgency urinary incontinence
Muscarinic receptor antagonists [607-610] and beta-3 agonist [297-299, 611-614] are currently the first-line 
pharmacological treatments for UUI. The mechanism of action, efficacy, and safety and tolerability profiles of 
both classes of drugs are discussed in detail in sections 5.2.3 and 5.2.4, respectively.
Antimuscarinic monotherapy can significantly improve urgency, UUI, and increased daytime frequency.
Mirabegron is superior to placebo and as efficacious as antimuscarinics for improvement of UUI.

Duloxetine led to a short-term improvement in postprostatectomy SUI symptoms and QoL 
improvement; however, a significant proportion of men discontinued treatment.
